intro: Calendula ranunculodes, commonly known as the meadow safflower, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of ray and disk florets. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and alternate, heart-shaped leaves. Its flowers are yellow to orange in color, blooming from late spring to early autumn. The plant is often found in meadows, grasslands, and along roadsides, and it is known for its medicinal and ornamental uses.
